If you stand with me right now, I will stand with you for the next six years – in line, in the rain, through hardships, and in triumph.

Let’s get this thing done one more time.

If you have any voting-related questions, you can call or text the Voter Protection Hotline at 1-888-730-5816.

And if you are over 75 or disabled, you can go to the FRONT of the line between 9:30 and 4:30 on Election Day.

I know it’s hard. But in the fight for Georgians, the hard work never ends.

So, when you get ready to vote, bring whatever your version of an apple, an orange, two books, and a toothbrush is.

We know what awaits us and we must be ready.

And staying in line means more than just securing your vote.

It means that despite all adversity, YOU are carrying the torch that John Lewis brought over the Edmund Pettus bridge to ensure your voice is heard.

But a long line to vote also means that the people are fighting back against those who want to silence us.

It means that the people are using their voice and exercising their most fundamental right in a democracy.

It means we are making ourselves heard.
They do this because they are afraid of the power of working folks. Of students. Of anyone who doesn’t have the luxury to take the whole day off to vote.

However, we still face barriers that were put in place by people who don’t want some people to vote.

Barriers like closing voting locations and limiting early and mail-in voting create lines so long they wrap around entire blocks.

Because of his tireless and fearless work, he bent the moral arc of the universe toward justice.

We honor and continue that work today by exercising that inalienable right that he fought for: voting.

When John Lewis crossed the Edmund Pettus Bridge to fight for civil and voting rights, he brought an apple, an orange, two books, toothpaste, and a toothbrush.

He came prepared because he knew what waited for him on the other side of that bridge.

Election Day is almost here, Georgia!

For too many of us, that will mean waiting in line to vote. So let’s talk about why we have voting lines and what they mean.
